'''Frank H. Ogawa Plaza''' is a historic location in the heart of downtown [[Oakland, California]].
==Location and elements== [[File:Ogawa Plaza.png|left|thumb|Ogawa plaza]] Frank H. Ogawa Plaza is located where Telegraph and San Pablo Avenues converge with Broadway and 14th Street. The west side of the plaza is the site of [[Oakland City Hall]] and [[Oakland Police Department|Oakland Police]] Headquarters. Around the plaza are several [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] styled commercial buildings from the early 20th century.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dinkelspiel Cerny|first=Susan|title=An Architectural Guidebook to San Francisco and the Bay Area|year=2007|publisher=Gibbs Smith|isbn=9781586854324|page=247}}</ref> New buildings have been constructed to fit visually with the older architecture.<ref>{{cite book|title=Fentress Bradburn: Selected and Current Works|year=1998|publisher=Images Publishing|isbn=9781875498864|page=188}}</ref>
The plaza is a {{convert|160000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} public space. Most of the plaza is composed of "The Commons", a raised lawn. The plaza also features "The Forum", or amphitheaterâa space for public gatherings and performances.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pyatok.com/portfolio/oaklandcityhallplaza.html | title=Oakland City Hall Plaza | publisher=Pyatok Architects | accessdate=November 8, 2011}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Musical Performance in Oscar Grant Plaza Amphitheater.jpg|thumb|The plaza amphitheater]] In 1896, the San Francisco Chronicle reported on a young [[Jack London]] giving speeches in what was then called "City Hall park".<ref>"Jack London, who is known as the boy socialist of Oakland, is holding forth nightly to the crowds that throng City Hall Park. There are other speakers in plenty, but London always gets the biggest crowd and the most respectful attention. the young man is a pleasant speaker, more earnest than eloquent, and while he is a broad socialist in every way, he is not an anarchist" [http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/JlondonJ.htm]</ref> The open space in front of the city hall was part of Oakland's Administrative Buildings project that included the redevelopment of the [[Oakland City Center|city center]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite book|last=Quatman|first=G. William|title=Design-Build for the Design Professional|year=2001|publisher=Aspen Law & Business|isbn=9780735517271|page=284}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Fowler|first=Carol|title=Insiders' Guide to Berkeley and the East Bay|year=2003|publisher=Globe Pequot Press|isbn=9780762723737|page=202}}</ref> 1998 marked the completion of the renovated plaza.{{cn|date=November 2011}}
Along with being the seat of government, the area has become part of the city's arts culture with the annual Arts and Soul Festival and publicly commissioned art.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Rough Guide to San Francisco & the Bay Area|first1=Mark|last1=Ellwood|first2=Nick|last2=Edwards|year=2009|publisher=Penguin Publishing|isbn=9781405384377|page=16}}</ref> In 2001, the city council commissioned a sculpture for the plaza from artist [[Bruce Beasley]]. The sculpture, ''Vitality'', was completed in 2002.<ref>[http://www.oaklandnet.com/government/council/reports/04-24-01/Council/221reso.pdf Resolution on Plaza Art]</ref><ref>SF Gate - 2001-02-16 [http://articles.sfgate.com/2001-02-16/news/17584238_1_public-art-obscene-gesture-bruce-beasley Oakland Sculptor Beasley Selected / Panel picks art for City Hall Plaza]</ref>
The plaza has been the site of various protests and other forms of civil disorder.
==Name of the plaza== In 1998, the [[Oakland#Government|Oakland City Council]] renamed City Hall Plaza as "Frank H. Ogawa Plaza"<ref name=Historytimeline>{{cite web|url= http://oaklandnet.com/celebrate/Historytimeline.htm |title= Oakland History Timeline |publisher= City of Oakland, Oakland History Room of the Oakland Public Library |accessdate= 2011-11-08 |quote= 1998 Named in honor of late Oakland City Councilmember Frank H. Ogawa, City Hall Plaza re-opens after a $124 million rebuilding.}}</ref> in honor of [[Frank H. Ogawa]]. Ogawa was a [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] leader<ref name=eshoo>{{cite web |url= http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-1994-07-21/html/CREC-1994-07-21-pt1-PgE6.htm |title= TRIBUTE TO FRANK H. OGAWA |first= Anna |last= Eshoo |authorlink= Anna Eshoo |date= 1994-07-21 |work= [[Congressional Record]] Volume 140, Number 96 |publisher= [[United States House of Representatives]] |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= 2011-10-31 |quote= Mr. Speaker, I rise today to pay tribute to Frank Ogawa--a dedicated public servant, outstanding civil rights leader, and loving husband and father--who passed away earlier this month in Oakland, California.}}</ref> and the first [[Japanese American]] to serve on the Oakland City Council<ref name=Historytimeline/> in which he served from 1966 until his death in 1994.<ref name=statue>{{cite video |last1= Allen |first1= Annalee |last2= Lee |first2= Sam |title= Oakland City Center: Frank H. Ogawa Statue (video) |url= http://video.ezinemark.com/exploring-the-oakland-city-center-oakland-city-center-frank-h.-ogawa-statue-44bf4d7e134.html |publisher= EzineMark.com |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate= 2011-10-31}}</ref> The plaza displays a bronze bust of Ogawa.
Members of [[Occupy Oakland]] began using Ogawa plaza as a main protest encampment starting on on October 10, 2011. Their presence has been criticize for potential health and safety concerns.<ref>http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19139574</ref> The protestors symbolically renamed Frank H. Ogawa Plaza as "Oscar Grant Plaza". [[Oscar Grant]] was a young Hayward man who was shot in the back by a [[Bay Area Rapid Transit]] police officer in 2009.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/10/30/occupy-oakland-the-oscar-grant-frank-ogawa-plaza-issue/ | title=Occupy Oakland: The Oscar Grant / Frank Ogawa Plaza Issue | first=Zennie | last=Abraham | date= 2011-10-30 | publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | accessdate= 2011-11-11 | archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6380s6A8K | archivedate= 2011-11-11 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
